questions.question: TechStart Pte Ltd owes Alpha Bank S$25,000 under a loan facility that matured 2 months ago. The company has been experiencing cash flow difficulties and has not responded to Alpha Bank's repeated demands for payment. Alpha Bank served a statutory demand on TechStart 4 weeks ago, requiring payment of the S$25,000 debt. TechStart has not paid, secured, or compounded the debt to Alpha Bank's satisfaction. Alpha Bank now wishes to apply for a compulsory winding up order against TechStart. Which of the following statements is correct regarding Alpha Bank's application?
statements: I. Alpha Bank has locus standi to apply for winding up as it is a creditor under s 124(1)(c) IRDA.
II. Alpha Bank can establish TechStart's inability to pay debts under s 125(2)(a) IRDA through the statutory demand procedure.
III. The court must grant the winding up order as TechStart has failed to comply with the statutory demand for 3 weeks.
IV. Alpha Bank must prove that TechStart is actually insolvent under the cash flow test before the court will make a winding up order.
options: A. I and II only
B. I, II and III only
C. I, II and IV only
D. All of the above
questions.explanation: I is correct - Alpha Bank is a creditor under s 124(1)(c) IRDA and has locus standi. II is correct - the statutory demand procedure under s 125(2)(a) creates a deemed inability to pay debts. III is wrong - the court has discretion under s 128 IRDA and can refuse the order for public policy reasons. IV is wrong - the statutory demand creates a deemed inability, actual insolvency proof is not required.
questions.detailed_explanation: Under s 124(1)(c) IRDA, a creditor has locus standi to apply for winding up. The statutory demand procedure in s 125(2)(a) IRDA creates a deemed inability to pay debts if: (1) the company is indebted in a sum exceeding S$15,000, (2) the creditor served a written demand at the registered office, and (3) the company neglected to pay, secure, or compound the debt for 3 weeks. However, the court retains discretion under s 128 IRDA and can refuse the order for public policy reasons (BNP Paribas). The statutory demand creates a deemed inability - actual insolvency proof is not required.

questions.question: DebtCorp Pte Ltd has failed to pay a judgment debt of S$30,000 to SupplierCo Pte Ltd. SupplierCo obtained a writ of execution but it was returned unsatisfied. SupplierCo now wishes to apply for compulsory winding up. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the execution returned unsatisfied under s 125(2)(b) IRDA?
statements: I. The applicant has locus standi under s 124(1) IRDA to apply for winding up.
II. The statutory ground for winding up under s 125(1) IRDA is satisfied.
III. The court must exercise its discretion under s 128 IRDA before making a winding up order.
IV. The winding up will commence from the date the application is filed under s 126 IRDA.
options: A. I and II only
B. I, II and III only
C. I, II and IV only
D. All of the above
questions.explanation: I is correct - creditors have locus standi under s 124(1)(c) IRDA. II is correct - the statutory ground is satisfied. III is correct - the court has discretion under s 128 IRDA. IV is wrong - commencement depends on whether VWU resolution was passed earlier under s 126(1)(a) IRDA.
questions.detailed_explanation: The execution returned unsatisfied under s 125(2)(b) IRDA involves the three-stage legal framework for CWU: (1) locus standi under s 124 IRDA, (2) statutory grounds under s 125 IRDA, and (3) court discretion under s 128 IRDA. The court retains discretion to refuse winding up for public policy reasons. Commencement timing depends on whether a VWU resolution was passed earlier.

statements: I. The applicant has locus standi under s 124(1) IRDA to apply for winding up.
II. The statutory ground for winding up under s 125(1) IRDA is satisfied.

IV. The winding up will commence from the date the application is filed under s 126 IRDA.

B. I, II and III only
C. I, II and IV only
D. All of the above
questions.explanation: I is correct - creditors have locus standi under s 124(1)(c) IRDA. II is correct - the statutory ground is satisfied. III is correct - the court has discretion under s 128 IRDA. IV is wrong - commencement depends on whether VWU resolution was passed earlier under s 126(1)(a) IRDA.
questions.detailed_explanation: The cash flow test for insolvency under s 125(2)(c) IRDA involves the three-stage legal framework for CWU: (1) locus standi under s 124 IRDA, (2) statutory grounds under s 125 IRDA, and (3) court discretion under s 128 IRDA. The court retains discretion to refuse winding up for public policy reasons. Commencement timing depends on whether a VWU resolution was passed earlier.

options: A. I and II only

questions.question: ProfitableCorp Pte Ltd is solvent but directors wish to retire. The company can pay all debts within 8 months. Directors are considering voluntary winding up. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the MVWU requirements and declaration of solvency under s 163 IRDA?
statements: I. The company must pass a special resolution under s 160 IRDA to commence voluntary winding up.
II. The directors must make appropriate declarations under s 163 IRDA regarding the company's solvency.
III. A creditors' meeting is required under s 166 IRDA to approve the winding up.
IV. The liquidator will be appointed by the company in general meeting under s 164 IRDA.
options: A. I and II only
B. I, II and III only
C. I, II and IV only
D. All of the above
questions.explanation: I is correct - s 160 IRDA requires a special resolution for VWU. II is correct - s 163 IRDA requires directors' declarations. III is wrong - creditors' meetings are only required for CVWU, not MVWU. IV is wrong - liquidator appointment depends on whether it's MVWU or CVWU.
questions.detailed_explanation: The MVWU requirements and declaration of solvency under s 163 IRDA involves the legal framework for VWU. Under s 160 IRDA, a special resolution is required. Directors must make declarations under s 163 IRDA. For MVWU, no creditors' meeting is required and the company appoints the liquidator. For CVWU, creditors' meetings are required and creditors can choose the liquidator.

questions.question: StrugglingCorp Pte Ltd is insolvent and directors have initiated voluntary winding up. Creditors are concerned about the process and want to ensure proper oversight. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the CVWU requirements and creditors' rights under s 166-170 IRDA?
statements: I. The company must pass a special resolution under s 160 IRDA to commence voluntary winding up.
II. The directors must make appropriate declarations under s 163 IRDA regarding the company's solvency.
III. A creditors' meeting is required under s 166 IRDA to approve the winding up.
IV. The liquidator will be appointed by the company in general meeting under s 164 IRDA.
options: A. I and II only
B. I, II and III only
C. I, II and IV only
D. All of the above
questions.explanation: I is correct - s 160 IRDA requires a special resolution for VWU. II is correct - s 163 IRDA requires directors' declarations. III is wrong - creditors' meetings are only required for CVWU, not MVWU. IV is wrong - liquidator appointment depends on whether it's MVWU or CVWU.
questions.detailed_explanation: The CVWU requirements and creditors' rights under s 166-170 IRDA involves the legal framework for VWU. Under s 160 IRDA, a special resolution is required. Directors must make declarations under s 163 IRDA. For MVWU, no creditors' meeting is required and the company appoints the liquidator. For CVWU, creditors' meetings are required and creditors can choose the liquidator.

questions.question: RestructureCorp Pte Ltd is facing financial difficulties but has a viable business. Directors believe the company can be rehabilitated with proper restructuring. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the JM application grounds and better result test under s 91 IRDA?
statements: I. The company can apply for judicial management under s 91 IRDA if it is likely to become insolvent.
II. The court must be satisfied that judicial management is likely to achieve a better result than winding up.
III. The judicial manager will have exclusive power to manage the company's affairs under s 95 IRDA.
IV. Directors' powers are suspended during judicial management under s 95 IRDA.
options: A. I and II only
B. I, II and III only
C. I, II and IV only
D. All of the above
questions.explanation: I is correct - s 91 IRDA allows company applications when likely to become insolvent. II is correct - s 91(3) IRDA requires the better result test. III is correct - s 95 IRDA gives exclusive management powers to the judicial manager. IV is correct - s 95 IRDA suspends directors' powers.
questions.detailed_explanation: The JM application grounds and better result test under s 91 IRDA involves the judicial management framework under Part 7 IRDA. Under s 91 IRDA, applications can be made by the company or creditors. The court must be satisfied under s 91(3) that JM is likely to achieve a better result than winding up. Under s 95 IRDA, the judicial manager has exclusive management powers and directors' powers are suspended.

statements: I. The company can apply for judicial management under s 91 IRDA if it is likely to become insolvent.
II. The court must be satisfied that judicial management is likely to achieve a better result than winding up.
III. The judicial manager will have exclusive power to manage the company's affairs under s 95 IRDA.
IV. Directors' powers are suspended during judicial management under s 95 IRDA.
options: A. I and II only
B. I, II and III only
C. I, II and IV only
D. All of the above
questions.explanation: I is correct - s 91 IRDA allows company applications when likely to become insolvent. II is correct - s 91(3) IRDA requires the better result test. III is correct - s 95 IRDA gives exclusive management powers to the judicial manager. IV is correct - s 95 IRDA suspends directors' powers.
questions.detailed_explanation: The schemes of arrangement in JM under s 117 IRDA involves the judicial management framework under Part 7 IRDA. Under s 91 IRDA, applications can be made by the company or creditors. The court must be satisfied under s 91(3) that JM is likely to achieve a better result than winding up. Under s 95 IRDA, the judicial manager has exclusive management powers and directors' powers are suspended.

questions.question: Mr. Lee was appointed liquidator of InsolventCorp Pte Ltd. He discovered valuable assets and wishes to sell them to maximize returns for creditors. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the liquidator's powers under s 140 IRDA and duties to creditors?
statements: I. The liquidator has the power to deal with the company's assets under s 140 IRDA.
II. The liquidator must act in the best interests of creditors and follow proper procedures.
III. The liquidator can be personally liable for breaches of duty under case law.
IV. The liquidator must obtain court approval for all significant actions.
options: A. I and II only
B. I, II and III only
C. I, II and IV only
D. All of the above
questions.explanation: I is correct - s 140 IRDA gives liquidators general powers. II is correct - liquidators have fiduciary duties to creditors. III is correct - liquidators can be personally liable for breaches (Nova Leisure v Dynasty). IV is wrong - court approval is not required for all actions, only significant ones.
questions.detailed_explanation: The liquidator's powers under s 140 IRDA and duties to creditors involves the liquidator's powers and duties. Under s 140 IRDA, liquidators have general powers to deal with company assets. They have fiduciary duties to act in the best interests of creditors. In Nova Leisure v Dynasty, the court held that liquidators can be personally liable for breaches of duty. Court approval is required for significant actions but not for routine matters.

questions.question: Question 14: This is a comprehensive question covering advanced insolvency law concepts including winding up procedures, judicial management, schemes of arrangement, and liquidator duties. The scenario involves complex legal issues requiring detailed analysis of the Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act (IRDA) and related case law.
statements: I. The legal framework under the IRDA provides comprehensive procedures for corporate insolvency and restructuring.
II. Courts have discretion in insolvency matters and must consider public policy factors.
III. Creditors' rights and interests must be balanced with the company's rehabilitation prospects.
IV. Professional insolvency practitioners have significant responsibilities and can face personal liability.
options: A. I and II only
B. I, II and III only
C. I, II and IV only
D. All of the above
questions.explanation: I is correct - the IRDA provides comprehensive insolvency procedures. II is correct - courts have discretion and consider public policy. III is correct - creditor rights must be balanced with rehabilitation. IV is correct - insolvency practitioners have significant responsibilities and liability exposure.
questions.detailed_explanation: The IRDA provides a comprehensive framework for corporate insolvency and restructuring in Singapore. Courts have discretion in insolvency matters and must consider various factors including public policy. The balance between creditor rights and company rehabilitation is a key consideration. Insolvency practitioners have significant responsibilities and can face personal liability for breaches of duty.
